heisig_chinese_memo: Under every tombstone is someone buried in the soil.
heisig_story: I don't like it any more than you do, but this kanji is not the pictograph it is trumped up to be: a mound of soil piled on the ground. All I can recommend is that you memorize it as it is. Anyway, it will be occurring with such frequency that you have almost no chance of forgetting it, even if you try.
koohiiStory1: Remembering soil is easy. If soil is soft, you can take a walking stick and plunge it two* feet into the ground.
koohiiStory2: King Arthur pulled the magical sword Excalibur out of the hardened soil to claim his place as king.

chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: Under every tombstone is someone buried in the soil.
origin_of_ch_char_book: The monument features the three supreme existences of the Universe: Heaven (å¤©), Earth(åœ°), and Human (äºº)â€” and the five basic elements of the universe: water(æ°´), fire(ç«), iron (é‡‘), wood(æœ¨), soil(åœŸ) (14th-19th century) ,Along with Heaven, the Earth was an object of worship. The people who developed the Hanzi system built an earthen pillar (åœŸ, tu, earth). In fact, the pillar means ten (å, shi, ten) which also means â€˜manyâ€™. So we can see this character describes the land from which many creatures sprout. The â€œShuo Wen Jie Zi (Explanation of Chinese Characters)â€ written about 2,000 years ago says that â€œ â€˜Tuâ€™ means that earth regurgitates living things.â€ In other words, all the living things came from the Earth. Therefore, in ancient society, it was very important to worship Mother Earth which gave birth to all living things.,Ancient eastern people worshiped the earth. So, they tried to preserve the natural land rather than cultivate and develop it. They thought of the earth as their mother because all the creatures come from the earth. (é‡Œ, li, place, inside) The upper one (ç”°, tian=tâ€™ien, field) means field divided into four places, and lower one (åœŸ, tu, soil) means the earth on which some corps are rising, and it also means an altar people gathering. The whole character means the village where people gather in the field, performing rites. In the past, people considered that the earth of their hometown would protect them, and they worshiped the god of their own territory by building an altar. This god of hometown would judge the people of the village whether to go to Heaven or to go to hell. (ç†, li, manage, reason) The left side of the symbol (ç‰, yu=yÃ¼, jade) is a jade bead, and the right side is a village where people live together. The ancient people believed that the jade are so pure than any other existences of the earth, and they believed that the jade is a soul of the land which can defeat the evil spirits. Because jade (ç‰) can judge people of the village with the spirit of the earth (åœŸ), is used as a meaning of control, manage, reason etc.,For ancient East Asian people, nature was to be revered. When they gazed upon the clear night skies and many stars above, they thought that the stars were like spirits of people. (æ˜Ÿ, xing=hsing star) When we see this character, it shows the green plants (å±®) coming up from the earth (åœŸ), which symbolizes full of life (ç”Ÿ, sheng, to live, life), and stars scattered around it (æ™¶, jing, brilliant; crystal). In ancient dictionary, it was explained that â€œstars are spirits of all living thingsâ€. According to the explanations, the stars or the constellations are related to the spirits of living things. Why did the ancient people connect the stars with the spirit?,The ancient Chinese considered that there were five essential elements in the universe: Water (æ°´, shui), Fire (ç«, huo), Wood (æœ¨, mu), Iron (é‡‘, jin), and Earth (åœŸ, tu). The five main elements interact and create each other or restrain each other. For example, the tree burns and creates fire which burns down to ashes and becomes earth (soil). Water restrains fire and fire can melt metal. (äº”, wu, five) contains such philosophical meanings. The top line means sky , the bottom line is earth , and the middle shows how the â€œfive elementsâ€ cross and interact with each other.,(é‡‘, jin, gold; metal) has a lid covering the top of the object and something under it (ä»Š, jin, now), and a soil beneath it (åœŸ, tu, soil), and some points dotted around them . As a whole, this character means gathering the shiny particles that are contained in the soil. It originally meant various metals contained in the soil, but later it came to mean gold.,Since vaccines were not discovered yet, there were many dogs with rabies. The English expression â€œrabid dogâ€ had a strong meaning back in those times. Dogs that had rabies went mad and bit people and showed ferocity. People had to be very careful not to be bitten by mad dogs. The character (ç‹‚, kuang, mad) describes this kind of situation. The left part of this character means a foot (æ­¢, zhi=chih, stop) on a high mound (åœŸ, tu, soil). On the right, there is a dog. In other words, it depicts someone stopped on a high place and a dog beneath it barking ferociously.
humanum_full_description_en:
The shape of a pile of dirt piled up on the ground (Xu Jinxiong, Li Xiaoding, Xu Zhongshu). The dots are like dirt particles. The original meaning is mound, and the extension means land. One said that it was like the god-lord who offered sacrifices to the land, which was later called the " community ." In ancient times, the earth was sealed and standing stones were used to worship the gods of the land (Peng Yushang, Dai Jiaxiang, Zhang Shichao). The little elephant gives a gift to the landlord (Shirakawa Jing).

Oracle read as " community " is the land of God (Wang Guowei), "Collection" 14395: "Liao in the soil." Jia Jinwen means territory and land, "Collection" 36975: "Xitu receives the year, lucky." It means that there is a good harvest in Xitu. Da Yuding: "Received by the People and Territory", "Shangshu. "Luo Gao": "Born to protect civil and martial arts by the people." It also means that the earth is opposite to the sky. Ai Cheng Shuding: "Always use gluttonous sacrifices, die in the soil, and take care of the public. Don't be slack." " Death " is interpreted as " corpse ", which means the chief priest, "Zuo Zhuan. "Five Years of Chenggong": "The Lord of the Mountains and Rivers", Du pre-annotated: "The Lord is the priest of the Suo." "Die in the soil" means the God of Mountains and Rivers (Ma Chengyuan). Five years of Yan Shenggui: "Publicity in the soil", equivalent to "Poetry. Lu Song. "Yugong": "Tutian vassals" (Sun Yirang). The inscription "ğ¤”²åœŸ" is an official name, which is equivalent to the "Situ" in the classics. It is in charge of land and agricultural production, and occasionally leads soldiers on expeditions and serves as a bridegroom. Nangong Hu Zhong: "ğ¤”²Tu Nangong Hu".

"Shuowen": "Earth, the earth spit out creatures. In the two things under the earth, things appear in shape. All the belongings of the earth come from the earth."
humanum_short_description_en: The shape of a pile of soil on the ground (Xu Jinxiong, Li Xiaoding, Xu Zhongshu). The dots are like dirt particles. The original meaning is mound, and the extension means land.

origin_of_ch_char_book: The monument features the three supreme existences of the Universe: Heaven (å¤©), Earth(åœ°), and Human (äºº)â€” and the five basic elements of the universe: water(æ°´), fire(ç«), iron (é‡‘), wood(æœ¨), soil(åœŸ) (14th-19th century),Along with Heaven, the Earth was an object of worship. The people who developed the Hanzi system built an earthen pillar (åœŸ, tu, earth). In fact, the pillar means ten (å, shi, ten) which also means â€˜manyâ€™. So we can see this character describes the land from which many creatures sprout. The â€œShuo Wen Jie Zi (Explanation of Chinese Characters)â€ written about 2,000 years ago says that â€œ â€˜Tuâ€™ means that earth regurgitates living things.â€ In other words, all the living things came from the Earth. Therefore, in ancient society, it was very important to worship Mother Earth which gave birth to all living things.,Ancient eastern people worshiped the earth. So, they tried to preserve the natural land rather than cultivate and develop it. They thought of the earth as their mother because all the creatures come from the earth. (é‡Œ, li, place, inside) The upper one (ç”°, tian=tâ€™ien, field) means field divided into four places, and lower one (åœŸ, tu, soil) means the earth on which some corps are rising, and it also means an altar people gathering. The whole character means the village where people gather in the field, performing rites. In the past, people considered that the earth of their hometown would protect them, and they worshiped the god of their own territory by building an altar. This god of hometown would judge the people of the village whether to go to Heaven or to go to hell. (ç†, li, manage, reason) The left side of the symbol (ç‰, yu=yÃ¼, jade) is a jade bead, and the right side is a village where people live together. The ancient people believed that the jade are so pure than any other existences of the earth, and they believed that the jade is a soul of the land which can defeat the evil spirits. Because jade (ç‰) can judge people of the village with the spirit of the earth (åœŸ), is used as a meaning of control, manage, reason etc.,For ancient East Asian people, nature was to be revered. When they gazed upon the clear night skies and many stars above, they thought that the stars were like spirits of people. (æ˜Ÿ, xing=hsing star) When we see this character, it shows the green plants (å±®) coming up from the earth (åœŸ), which symbolizes full of life (ç”Ÿ, sheng, to live, life), and stars scattered around it (æ™¶, jing, brilliant; crystal). In ancient dictionary, it was explained that â€œstars are spirits of all living thingsâ€. According to the explanations, the stars or the constellations are related to the spirits of living things. Why did the ancient people connect the stars with the spirit?,The ancient Chinese considered that there were five essential elements in the universe: Water (æ°´, shui), Fire (ç«, huo), Wood (æœ¨, mu), Iron (é‡‘, jin), and Earth (åœŸ, tu). The five main elements interact and create each other or restrain each other. For example, the tree burns and creates fire which burns down to ashes and becomes earth (soil). Water restrains fire and fire can melt metal. (äº”, wu, five) contains such philosophical meanings. The top line means sky , the bottom line is earth , and the middle shows how the â€œfive elementsâ€ cross and interact with each other.,(é‡‘, jin, gold; metal) has a lid covering the top of the object and something under it (ä»Š, jin, now), and a soil beneath it (åœŸ, tu, soil), and some points dotted around them . As a whole, this character means gathering the shiny particles that are contained in the soil. It originally meant various metals contained in the soil, but later it came to mean gold.,Since vaccines were not discovered yet, there were many dogs with rabies. The English expression â€œrabid dogâ€ had a strong meaning back in those times. Dogs that had rabies went mad and bit people and showed ferocity. People had to be very careful not to be bitten by mad dogs. The character (ç‹‚, kuang, mad) describes this kind of situation. The left part of this character means a foot (æ­¢, zhi=chih, stop) on a high mound (åœŸ, tu, soil). On the right, there is a dog. In other words, it depicts someone stopped on a high place and a dog beneath it barking ferociously.

The shape of a pile of dirt piled up on the ground (Xu Jinxiong, Li Xiaoding, Xu Zhongshu). The dots are like dirt particles. The original meaning is mound, and the extension means land. One said that it was like the god-lord who offered sacrifices to the land, which was later called the " community." In ancient times, the earth was sealed and standing stones were used to worship the gods of the land (Peng Yushang, Dai Jiaxiang, Zhang Shichao). The little elephant gives a gift to the landlord (Shirakawa Jing). Oracle read as " community" is the land of God (Wang Guowei), "Collection" 14395: "Liao in the soil." "Luo Gao": "Born to protect civil and martial arts by the people." It also means that the earth is opposite to the sky. Ai Cheng Shuding: "Always use gluttonous sacrifices, die in the soil, and take care of the public. Don't be slack." " Death" is interpreted as " corpse", which means the chief priest, "Zuo Zhuan. "Five Years of Chenggong": "The Lord of the Mountains and Rivers", Du pre-annotated: "The Lord is the priest of the Suo." "Die in the soil" means the God of Mountains and Rivers (Ma Chengyuan). Five years of Yan Shenggui: "Publicity in the soil", equivalent to "Poetry. Lu Song. "Yugong": "Tutian vassals" (Sun Yirang).
